1997.Description: A significant measles outbreak occurred due to lower vaccination rates and gaps in immunization coverage, highlighting the need for better vaccine uptake.

2012.Description: A notable outbreak started with a man returning from Thailand, leading to 167 cases in southwest Sydney. This event emphasized the impact of international travel and the presence of unvaccinated communities.

2014.Description: The World Health Organization declared measles eliminated in Australia. However, measles cases continued to be imported from other countries, posing a constant threat.

2018.Description: Smaller outbreaks occurred, particularly in regions with lower vaccination rates and among populations with higher vaccine hesitancy, such as certain migrant communities and areas with vaccine misinformation.

2019.Description: Australia experienced another spike in measles cases, largely due to international travel and decreased vaccination rates in specific age groups. This outbreak reinforced the importance of maintaining high immunization coverage.

2022.Description: The global increase in measles cases, partly due to disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, also affected Australia. Despite overall high vaccination rates, areas with lower coverage remained at risk for outbreaks.
